description:
In a world where students rely more and more on digital technology and AI for learning, English majors Avryl Bender and Jayda Smith were tasked with “researching the ungoogleable” during their summer internship with Poetry Matters. 

During their internship, Avryl and Jayda conducted research on Dr. Barbara Althea Jones—a Trinidadian-born poet, plant geneticist, and professor at McGill during the sixties. 

“In the archive, time moved differently. Gradually, the past and present seemed to fold into each other. Both of us remember particular moments when the archive prompted us to feel that we really knew Jones,” Avryl and Jayda share their experience working in the Barbara Althea Jones fonds within the McGill University Archives. 

Keep an eye out on the Poetry Matters website (https://www.mcgill.ca/poetrymatters/) for Avryl and Jayda’s forthcoming portrait of Dr. Barbara Althea Jones and make sure to read the full article via the link in our bio. 

#mcgill #mcgillarts #poetrymatters #artsinternship

One month left to apply for the Pathy Foundation Fellowship!

The Pathy Foundation Fellowship is a 12-month experiential-learning program in youth leadership and community engagement. Each year, up to 12 selected Fellows receive state-of-the-art training, extensive support, and $50,000 in funding to support their growth as leaders, make a meaningful impact in a community they care about, and acquire skills that will benefit them for a lifetime.

This is the only program in Canada that provides young people with a fully-funded opportunity to dedicate a year of their early career to a project they are passionate about, in any field, sector, and community across the world. 

Applications are open until December 15th, 2024! Learn more and start your application at www.pathyfellowship.com!

#mcgillarts #mcgill 
#TransformYourFuture #CommunityDevelopment #EmergingLeaders #Leadership
#YoungLeaders
The sun is shining on campus today 😎

On November 15, the Yan P. Lin Centre will be hosting a public symposium, “Rupture and Continuity in History” at the Faculty Club.

Organized by the Centre’s Research Group on Global Pasts and the Research Group on Transitions and Global Modernities, the two panel discussions will feature #McGillArts professors from the Department of History and Classical Studies, the Department of Political Science and the Department of Art History and Communication Studies.

This event is free to attend and open to the public.

Happy Thursday to all of our followers 🍁☀️

#mcgill #mcgillu #campus #montreal

In our last Faculty Publication Spotlight we spoke to Camille Owens, assistant professor of English, about her latest book, “Like Children: Black Prodigy and the Measure of the Human in America”, published by New York University Press in October 2024. 

It was during her time as a graduate student at Yale University that Owens came across a photograph of Oscar Moore, who would grace the cover of her first book years later. 

Oscar Moore, a black, blind child who performed across American stages as a prodigy during the 1880s-1890s, prompted Owens to look into the status and treatment of black children in both its historical and contemporary context. 

“Upon finding [this picture of Moore], I immediately wanted to know who Moore was, and why, in a period where white supremacists were relentlessly questioning black intelligence, this child’s intelligence—or “brightness”—held entertainment value for white Americans,” says Owens. 

Swipe through to read excerpts from our interview with Owens and access the full interview via the link in our bio. 
#mcgillarts #mcgillartsresearch

In September, the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council (SSHRC) announced the recipients of the 2024 Insight Grants and Insight Development Grants. 

26 researchers from the Faculty of Arts are among the recipients.

From research on rural lives in Canada to literature in the age of AI, the Insight grants support research proposed by emerging and established scholars. 

Read the full list via the link in our bio.
#mcgillarts #mcgillartsresearch #research #sshrc
